fullText:
Search for tetraquark candidate Zð4430Þ in meson photoproduction
Xiao-Hai Liu1 and Qiang Zhao1,2,3
1Institute of High Energy Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, People’s Republic of China
2Department of Physics, University of Surrey, Guildford, GU2 7XH, United Kingdom
3Theoretical Physics Center for Science Facilities, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, People’s Republic of China
Frank E. Close
Rudolf Peierls Centre for Theoretical Physics, University of Oxford, Keble Road, Oxford, OX1 3NP, United Kingdom
(Received 27 February 2008; published 8 May 2008)
We propose a search for the newly discovered tetraquark candidate Zð4430Þ in photoproduction. Based
on the Belle results, we show that if Zð4430Þ is a genuine resonance, its significantly large coupling to  0
will cause it to stand out above the background in p! Zþð4430Þn!  0þn. We consider the
dependence of the cross section for the quantum numbers (JP ¼ 1, 1þ, or 0).
DOI: 10.1103/PhysRevD.77.094005 PACS numbers: 12.39.Mk, 12.40.Vv, 13.60.r
I. INTRODUCTION
A resonant structure in the invariant mass of  0þ at
4.43 GeV with a width of 45 MeV was recently reported by
Belle in B! K 0 [1]. This result immediately provoked
much interest from experiment and theory due to the
possibility of it being a tetraquark candidate [2–6] with
flavor c cu d or c cd u, i.e. a charmonium with isospin I ¼ 1.
It has also been proposed that this structure may be due
to subthreshold effects in D D1 rescattering [7–11].
Similar to the Xð3872Þ which is proposed to be a possible
bound state of D D due to long-range  exchange forces
[12–14], such a mechanism will favor JP ¼ 0, 1, or 2
for Zð4430Þwith I ¼ 1 [11]. Also, it has been suggested by
Maiani et al. [4] that the strong coupling of the Zð4430Þ to
 0 instead of J=  could be a signal for a radially
excited 1þ tetraquark. Long ago, Close and Lipkin [15]
proposed that c cþ  is a channel that could identify
tetraquark states such as 1þ in S-wave or, most interest-
ing, 1 in P-wave, hence we shall also consider that
Zð4430Þ !  0 occurs via P-wave transition if it has
JPC ¼ 1. In particular, a large coupling to  0 will
have special implications for its photoproduction rate,
and information about its quantum numbers may be
extracted.
Seeing this state in an independent production process
will be essential for establishing its existence and deter-
mining its nature. We propose here to look for the Zð4430Þ
in photoproduction. If Zð4430Þ is a genuine signal for a
tetraquark state which couples to  0, then it can neces-
sarily be photoproduced via  exchange through the 
 0 intermediate coupling. It suggests that p!
Zþð4430Þn!  0þn could be a dominant production
mechanism for Zð4430Þ. Therefore, by looking for the
signal of Zð4430Þ in p! Zþð4430Þn!  0þn, one
may establish this state as a genuine resonance. We also
estimate a possible destructive interference from the inter-
mediate  J= coupling. Although Belle does not see
the decay of Zð4430Þ ! J= , which implies a weaker
ZJ=  coupling, the relatively larger leptonic width for
J= ! eþe than  0 ! eþe may still lead to sizable
contributions from intermediate J= in photoproduction.
We will investigate such effects in a vector meson domi-
nance (VMD) model.
In addition, we consider background contributions to
this channel which involve Pomeron exchanges and nu-
cleon Born terms. Interestingly, this shows that these back-
grounds have rather small interferences with the Zþð4430Þ
production. This enhances the possibility of identifying or
refuting this state in photoproduction. Experimental data
from DESY may be able to clarify this directly.
In the following we first provide a detailed description of
the theoretical model by considering Zð4430Þ to have
either JP ¼ 1, 1þ, or 0. The model predictions for the
differential and total cross sections will be presented. We
then make a quantitative analysis of the possible back-
ground contributions to  0N final state. Dalitz plot analy-
sis will be provided.
II. THE MODEL
The production of Zþ in p! Zþn can be described by
the processes in Fig. 1. Its production possesses different
(a) (b)
FIG. 1. Z production through meson exchange.
PHYSICAL REVIEW D 77, 094005 (2008)
1550-7998=2008=77(9)=094005(11) 094005-1  2008 The American Physical Society
features at different kinematics. We outline those features
below as they are essential for constructing the theoretical
model:
(I) In the t-channel, as the electromagnetic (EM) inter-
action does not conserve isospin, the Zð4430Þ can be
produced by either isoscalar or isovector exchange.
Taking into account the flavor content, i.e. Zþ has a
hidden c c which does not carry isospin, the isoscalar
exchange in the t-channel will be forbidden for the
charged Zð4430Þ while suppressed for the neutral
partner. We will come back to this point later.
Furthermore, as the Zð4430Þ has only been seen in
the  0 channel, we shall concentrate on the
t-channel pion exchange as a leading contribution.
We shall argue that this is likely to give a lower limit
for the photoproduction cross section. We note in
advance that the inclusion of e.g. a0 exchange will
increase the cross sections since there is no interfer-
ence between the pion and a0 exchange amplitudes.
We will present some numerical estimates for the
a0ð980Þ exchange later. Heavier t-channel meson
(Regge) exchanges contribute to the cross section
at off-forward angles and could become important in
the higher energy region. As we do not have infor-
mation about their couplings to Zð4430Þ 0, we shall
focus on the near-threshold region where the domi-
nant pion exchange can be well constrained and
reliably estimated.
(II) For JP ¼ 1 and 0, Zð4430Þ will couple to VP in
P-wave at leading order, while for JP ¼ 1þ, it is via
S-wave. We apply different effective Lagrangians to
describe the Z 0 vertex.
(III) There is no available information about the coupling
for a Z to nucleons. This will appear in the s or
u-channel where Zð4430Þ can directly couple to p
and n. The s-channel process generally becomes
important near threshold, and at middle and back-
ward scattering angles. With increasing energies,
these contributions die out quickly due to the sup-
pression of the s and u-channel propagators and the
effects of the nucleon’s form factors. In contrast, the
t-channel pion exchange may remain dominant at
forward angles and give the major contribution to the
cross section.
Based on the above rather general considerations,
we identify processes that will drive the Zð4430Þ
production. As the Zð4430Þ is observed to couple
strongly to  0, we propose to look for signals
in p!Zþð4430Þn! 0þn, and p!
Z0ð4430Þp! 00p. This gives rise to some back-
ground contributions as shown in Fig. 2, in particu-
lar, in the neutral Zð4430Þ production.
(IV) As the Zð4430Þ is observed to couple to  0, we
derive the Z coupling by vector meson domi-
nance (VMD), and assume that the Z coupling is
due to a sum of intermediate vector mesons which
connect the photon with the Zð4430Þ and the ex-
changed . We initially assume that  0 is the domi-
nant intermediate vector meson in the Z
coupling, and then consider the possible effect of a
coupling to J= .
A. Production of Zð4430Þ with JP ¼ 1
For JP ¼ 1, the following Lagrangian is applied for the
Z 0 coupling, e.g. for the charged Zð4430Þ:

In the Appendix, we provide the analogous expressions
for t-channel a0 exchange. Note that the pion and a0
exchanges contribute to the real and imaginary part of
the transition amplitude, respectively. Thus, there are no
interferences between these two channels, and the inclu-
sion of the a0 exchange will enhance the Zð4430Þ cross
section. As we lack knowledge on the Z 0a0 and a0NN
coupling strengths, which are in any event expected to be
much smaller than the  exchange contributions, we will
focus on the pion exchange here.
SEARCH FOR TETRAQUARK CANDIDATE Zð4430Þ IN . . . PHYSICAL REVIEW D 77, 094005 (2008)
094005-3
For neutral Z production contributions may also be
allowed from Pomeron exchange. However, we argue
that this scenario is suppressed due to the following rea-
sons: (i) In the case where the photon (isoscalar compo-
nent) couples to c c, isospin has to be transferred to the pair
of light q q in order to form Z0ð4430Þ. (ii) The photon can
couple to isovector vector mesons made of light q q, which
then pull out a pair of c c after exchanging a Pomeron.
Although this process conserves isospin, it is suppressed by
the soft creation of a large mass c c, and also as it requires
the Z meson to be formed with the q q and c c pairs at
relatively large momentum transfers. Consequently, sup-
pression from the final state wave function is likely. Precise
estimates will be model dependent but for the purpose of
estimating a lower limit for the production cross section,
we neglect this contribution here.
In contrast, Pomeron contributions can generate back-
ground. As shown in Figs. 2(a) and 2(b), the direct pro-
duction of  0 allows Pomeron exchanges as an important
production mechanism. An intermediate nucleon will then
decay into a pion and nucleon. In principle, all the inter-
mediate isospin 1=2 nucleon resonances can contribute to
this process. Again, as a simple estimate of the back-
ground, we only consider the nucleon pole contributions.
B. Production of Zð4430Þ with JP ¼ 1þ
For the production of Zð4430Þ with JP ¼ 1þ, the differ-
ence from JPC ¼ 1 is at the Z 0 vertex for which the
following effective Lagrangian is adopted [21,22]:
L Z 0 ¼

Interestingly, the neutral Z0 !  00 has JPC ¼ 0,
which is an exotic quantum number.
D. Numerical results for p! Zþn
In Figs. 3–5, the differential and total cross sections are
plotted for JP ¼ 1, 1þ, and 0, respectively. The photon
XIAO-HAI LIU, QIANG ZHAO, AND FRANK E. CLOSE PHYSICAL REVIEW D 77, 094005 (2008)
094005-4
energy for the differential cross sections is E ¼ 30 GeV
(W ¼ 7:56 GeV), which corresponds to the peaking en-
ergy region in the total cross sections. In all three cases, the
forward peaking turns to be a prominent feature in the
differential cross sections due to the pion exchange.
The results of Figs. 3–5 show compatible production
cross sections for those three spin-parity assignments. For
spin-parity 1 and 1þ, their production cross sections have
the same expression in the real photon limit as noted
before. The difference between Figs. 3 and 4 arises from
the different coupling strengths for gZ 0 extracted from
Zþ !  0þ.
The cross section for 0 production is found larger than
the other two assignments. This is understandable by com-
paring Eqs. (11), (15), and (20) with each other. It also
shows that, in order to determine the quantum numbers,
measurement of the angular distributions of Z!  0 is
necessary. For spin-parity 1þ, the decay will be via relative
S-wave between  0, while it is via relative P-wave for 1
and 0. Therefore, an observation of P-wave decay will
require further studies such as polarization observables to
determine the quantum numbers of Zð4430Þ.
For 0, a0 exchange is forbidden and the pion exchange
is the exclusive leading contribution. For other JP a0 could
contribute but in practice need not concern us here. Even
were its coupling as large as that of the pion, gZ 0a0 ¼
gZ 0, its contribution to the cross section is negligible (in
Figs. 3 and 4, the results due to t-channel a0 exchanges are
presented by the dotted curves). This in practice allows us
to focus on the pion exchange mechanism in the photo-
production reaction as a reliable estimate of the lower
bound of the production cross sections.
Because of the pion exchange, the energy dependence of
the total cross sections exhibits a strong threshold enhance-
ment in p! Zþn. It is similar to the charged   meson
production near threshold where the charged pion ex-
change (unnatural parity exchange) also plays a dominant
role [23,24]. However, such a threshold enhancement
seems to be absent in charmonium production, such as
J= and  0 [25,26]. This may be due to the dominance
of the diffractive process which submerges the contribu-
tions from t-channel unnatural parity exchanges. Although
J= has a relatively large coupling to  , whereby
t-channel pion exchange turns to be important in p!
J= p, the coupling is not as large as that for Z 0.
Consequently, the predicted threshold enhancement in Z
meson photoproduction is strongly driven by the large
Z 0 coupling.
Our main concern therefore is the possibility of some
further contribution that is large and destructive. The most

If the Z meson is a genuine resonance, the threshold
enhancement will be a signature for its existence. This can
be further clarified by the study of background effects in
p!  0þn in the next section.
III. BACKGROUND ANALYSIS
Experimentally, the final state particles identified are  0,
, and nucleon. As a result, background contributions to
the  0N channel can interfere with the transitions we are
interested in. As discussed earlier, one of the major con-
tributions is due to the diffractive production of  0 (Fig. 2).
In this section, we combine p! Zþn!  0þn and
p!  0p!  0þn together to make an estimate of the
signal and background contributions. This could be useful
for experimental search for the Zþ in this channel. Since
the production rate for all these three spin parities are
similar, we only consider JP ¼ 1 in the following
analysis.
The schematic transition diagrams are illustrated in
Fig. 2. We first extend the formulas of the previous section
to p! Zþn!  0þn, and then include the diffractive
contributions from the Pomeron exchanges.
A. Meson exchange terms
By including the vertex coupling for Zþ !  0þ, the
transition amplitude for pion exchange can be explicitly
written down:

B. Pomeron-exchange term
Pomeron as a phenomenology accounting for the dif-
fractive transitions has been widely studied in the literature
[27–29]. In this approach, the Pomeron mediates the long-
range interaction between a confined quark and a nucleon,
and has been shown to behave just like a C ¼ þ1 isoscalar
photon.
The Pomeron-nucleon coupling is determined by the
vertex:
FðtÞ ¼ 30fðtÞ; (33)

the coupling constants between a single Pomeron and a
light constituent quark, and fðtÞ is the isoscalar nucleon
electromagnetic form factor:

SEARCH FOR TETRAQUARK CANDIDATE Zð4430Þ IN . . . PHYSICAL REVIEW D 77, 094005 (2008)
094005-7
photoproduction [29], the coupling c for  
0 is deter-
mined. We note that these parameters lead to a reasonable
description of both J= and  0 photoproduction in com-
parison with the experiment [31].
As shown by the total production cross section for p!
Zþn, the largest cross section is at W ’ 8 GeVðE ’
34 GeVÞ. We thus take this energy as an input to simulate
the invariant mass spectrum for p!  0þn. This could
be the kinematic region which favors the separation of the
Zþ signals.
In Fig. 6, we calculate the total cross sections for p!
 0þn including both signal and background contribu-
tions. As shown by the solid curve, the overall production
cross section has a quick increase just above threshold and
is dominated by the Zþ production as shown by the dotted
curve. In contrast, the background contributions from the
Pomeron exchange are relatively small and do not vary
drastically with the increasing energies at W > 20 GeV.
This is consistent with the familiar diffractive behavior in
vector meson photoproduction.
The steep rise of the cross section near threshold turns
out to be very different from other known heavy vector
photoproductions, such as  , J= , and  0. In those cases,
the threshold cross sections are rather smooth and no
threshold enhancement has been observed. In the produc-
tion of Zþð4430Þ, its strong coupling to  0 gives rise to
the predominant contributions from pion exchange. Note
that  0 ! eþe is also strong. These lead to an unusual
prediction for its cross section near threshold.
It is more constructive to inspect the Dalitz plot for the
three-body final state. We take a sample of the events at
W ¼ 8 and 12 GeV, respectively. As shown by Fig. 7, a
clear band appears in the invariant mass spectrum of  0
due to the Z resonance. Although we do not include the s
and u channel nucleon resonances, their contributions
seem not to demolish the Zð4430Þ band since their effects
will add to the plot horizontally and in the lowM2n region,
e.g. M2n < 5 GeV
2.
With the increasing center-mass energy, the background
from Pomeron exchange becomes important, and the
Zð4430Þ signals are submerged as shown by Fig. 8.
For the neutral Z0ð4430Þ production, the leading back-
ground contribution is the same as the charged Z produc-
tion. In the t-channel Z0 production, an additional
transition is the diffractive production of Z0 via Pomeron
exchange for 1 or odderon exchange for 1þ. It gives rise
to two possibilities as shown in Fig. 9. In Fig. 9(a), the
initial photon couples to the isoscalar component of a
vector meson (c c), which then couples to Z0 by projecting
the c c component to the I ¼ 1 tetraquark wave function.
Note that the exchange of Pomeron or odderon does not
compensate the isospin. This process will be suppressed
due to isospin violation. The other diffractive transition is
that the initial photon couples to the isovector component
of the intermediate meson as shown by Fig. 9(b). For the
tetraquark scenario, the isovector component must be from
the light q q instead of c c, hence requiring creation of a pair
of c c from the vacuum which then couples to the I ¼ 1
tetraquark wave function. Note that the c c pair is much
heavier than the light q q. To form a tetraquark of cq c q , it
needs a sizable overlap between the final state Z0 and the
intermediate isovector q q. Since the c c is much heavier
than the light q q, the Z0 wave function overlap with the c c
and light q q should be small. This allows us to neglect the

Pomeron or odderon exchange contributions to the direct
Z0 production via diffractive processes. Because of the
above argument, the neutral Z0 photoproduction turns out
to be similar to the charged Z production studied earlier.
The neutral Z0 of 0 assignment leads to production of
exotic quantum number 0. If indeed the Z0ð4430Þ !
 00 has a partial width of
45 MeV, its photoproduction
cross section near threshold will also be significant. By
measuring the angular distribution of Z0 !  00, its quan-
tum numbers can also be determined.
IV. CONCLUSION
In this work we have made a detailed analysis of the
photoproduction reaction p! Zþð4430Þn in an effective
Lagrangian approach for possible assignments of JP ¼ 1,
1þ, and 0 to the Z0ð4430Þ. As suggested by the observa-
tion of Belle, we show that the t-channel pion exchange is
an important production mechanism for creating Zþð4430Þ
at the rate of several tens of nanobarn. In this process the
NN coupling can be well constrained and the Z
coupling can be extracted from the Z 0 data via VMD
model.
We have also checked the possible effect of t-channel a0
exchange. We find its contributions are relatively small
even if, as an upper limit, we fix the Z 0a0 coupling to
be the same as gZ 0. Since there is no interference be-
tween the a0 and pion exchange amplitudes, we can ne-
glect the a0 exchange in the calculation and only adopt the
relatively well-defined pion exchange for estimating the
lower bound of the Zð4430Þ photoproduction cross sec-
tions. We find that, due to pion exchange, a clear threshold
enhancement is predicted for Zð4430Þ photoproduction,
which is different from photoproduction of J= and  0
near threshold, and could be a signature for the Zð4430Þ
existence. This is also the kinematic region that uncertain-
ties arising from other unknown processes can be over-
looked as a reasonable approximate.
We also consider possible background contributions to
the signals in p!  0þn, where the diffractive produc-
tion of  0 turns to be the leading source. Interestingly, it
shows that the interferences from the background terms are
rather small. In the Dalitz plot at W ¼ 8 GeV (E ’
34 GeV), a clear band of the Z meson signals appear in
the invariant mass spectrum of  0. Similar results are
obtained for the neutral production channel. For other
background contributions from diffractive transitions, we
argue that they may be suppressed by isospin conservation
and momentummismatching. Although nucleon resonance
contributions to the background in Figs. 2(a) and 2(b) have
not been included in this calculation, their effects are
unlikely to submerge the Zð4430Þ band in the Dalitz plot.
The reason is that the nucleon resonance cross sections will
accumulate horizontally in a form of uneven bands, and be
located at M2n < 5 GeV
2. In the kinematics of higher
M2n interferences from the nucleon resonances are ex-
pected to be negligible. As a consequence, the Zð4430Þ
production signals can be rather cleanly isolated from the
background, and the measurement of the angular distribu-
tions between  0 and  will tell whether they are in a
relative S or P wave. The quantum numbers of the Zð4430Þ
can thus be determined.
In summary, in order to establish the Zð4430Þ as a
concrete candidate of tetraquark state and determine its
quantum numbers, further search for its signals in other

production processes is necessary. Supposing it is a genu-
ine resonance with sizable partial decay width to  0 [1],
we have argued that photoproduction should be useful for
providing a clear and consistent evidence for its existence.
Experimental data which have been collected at H1 and
ZEUS may already contain such information.
